solution.text:
volume of fluid inside the box = volume of the box - volume of the 100 spheres
volume of the box = volume of the cuboid=\(l\times b \times h\), where \(l\) is length, \(b\) is width and \(h\) is height
\(\Rightarrow \) Volume of the cuboid\(=_{{20*k}}_ \times _{{4*k}}_ \times _{{10*k}}_=_{{800*k*k*k}}_\)
Now volume of the sphere\(=\frac 43 \times[\pi \times r^3]\) where radius(r) of the sphere=\(_{k}_\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac 43 \times \frac {22}7 \times _{k}_^3=_{{trunc(pi_val*k*k*k*4/3,2)}}_\)
Volume of the 100 rasgullas=\(100\times _{{trunc(pi_val*k*k*k*4/3,2)}}_=_{{trunc(100*pi_val*k*k*k*4/3,2)}}_\)
Volume of the fluid\(=_{{800*k*k*k}}_ -_{{trunc(100*pi_val*k*k*k*4/3,2)}}_\)
\(\Rightarrow _{{trunc(800*k*k*k-100*pi_val*k*k*k*4/3,2)}}_\,cm^3\)

content.text:
A factory packs rasgullas in a cuboidal box of length= _{{10*k}}_cm, width= _{{4*k}}_cm and height= _{{20*k}}_cm
The rasgullas are in the shape of a sphere of radius _{k}_cm.
If the boxes are packed with 100 rasgullas and the complete box is filled with a sweet fluid
Find the volume of the fluid in the box
